example.crop-mapping-and-monitoring.desc: Remote sensing is widely used in crop mapping and monitoring by providing accurate and up-to-date information on various crop parameters such as crop type, extent, and health. It enables farmers to monitor crop growth and development, detect changes in crop health, and optimize crop management practices.
example.soil-moisture-monitoring.descrip: Remote sensing plays an important role in soil moisture monitoring by providing accurate and high-resolution data on soil moisture content. It enables farmers to optimize irrigation practices, reduce water use, and increase crop yield while maintaining soil health.
example.irrigation-management.descriptio: Managing and monitoring water resources in agriculture to ensure sustainable usage.
example.pest-and-disease-detection.descr: Early detection of crop pests and diseases through satellite and drone imagery analysis.
example.soil-health-monitoring.descripti: Monitoring soil quality and nutrients using remote sensing to improve crop health.
example.land-suitability-mapping.descrip: Remote sensing plays a critical role in land suitability mapping by providing accurate and high-resolution data on various land parameters such as topography, soil properties, and climate. It enables farmers to identify suitable land for various crops, optimize crop management practices, and increase economic returns.
example.climate-change-impact-analysis.d: Remote sensing helps in studying the long-term changes in agricultural patterns and practices due to climate change. It aids in understanding the shifts in crop suitability, growing seasons, and water availability.
example.border-surveillance.description: Monitoring and securing national borders using satellite imagery and aerial reconnaissance to detect unauthorized crossings and activities.
example.disaster-response-and-management: By providing accurate and up-to-date information on various disaster parameters such as flood extent, earthquake damage, and wildfire spread. It enables disaster management agencies to make informed decisions about emergency response and relief operations and to ensure efficient and effective disaster management.
example.urban-security-monitoring.descri: Enhancing urban security through the use of GIS mapping and real-time surveillance to identify and manage potential threats.
example.maritime-domain-awareness.descri: Enhancing urban security through the use of GIS mapping and real-time surveillance to identify and manage potential threats. Authorities can detect and track maritime traffic, including piracy, smuggling, and illegal fishing activities.
example.infrastructure-protection-and-mo: Using remote sensing to monitor critical infrastructure such as power grids, communication networks, and transportation systems for potential risks or ground displacements.
example.military-operations-planning.des: Leveraging GIS for strategic planning, troop deployment, and operational support in military contexts. Terrain analysis is another critical application of remote sensing technology in defense and security operations. By analyzing data from remote sensors, military planners can develop detailed and accurate maps and models of the operational area, including terrain features, vegetation, and infrastructure.
example.emergency-evacuation-planning.de: Using GIS to plan and execute emergency evacuation routes and strategies in disaster-prone areas.
example.illegal-activity-monitoring.desc: Detecting and analyzing illegal activities such as poaching, smuggling, unauthorized land use, Illegal buildings and illegal quarries through remote sensing.
example.asset-and-resource-tracking.desc: Monitoring and managing the location and distribution of assets and resources in defense and security operations.
Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) using GIS and remote sensing involves collecting and analyzing spatial data to evaluate the potential environmental effects of proposed projects. GIS maps the project area, identifying sensitive sites and predicting impacts, while remote sensing monitors changes over time. This process aids in decision-making, planning mitigation strategies, and monitoring post-project environmental compliance.
example.precision-farming.description: Harvesting more per acre while spending less on fertilizer using precision farming and software.
example.disease-control.description: Combating the spread of pests by identifying critical intervention areas and efficiently targeting control interventions.
example.swiss-alps-farming.description: Cultivating south-facing slopes in the Swiss Alps using aspect data because it shelters from cold and dry winds which is critical to successful crop growth.
example.3d-scanners-for-biomass.descript: Measuring with laser accuracy 3D biomass using the FARO scanner.
example.real-time-crop-yields.descriptio: Shifting to real-time crop monitoring and targeted, automated responses with drones and precision watering sensors.
example.current-food-security.descriptio: Safeguarding food insecure populations by establishing underlying causes through satellite, mobile-collected, and GIS data storage.
example.agri-tourism.description: avigating through crop mazes with GPS receivers in the developing field of agri-tourism.
example.plant-hardiness.description: Defining distinct boundaries in which plants are capable of growing as defined by climatic conditions.
example.machine-performance.description: Logging geographic coordinates of agricultural machinery in a farm field to better understand the spatial variability cost of field operation and machinery performance.
example.future-food-demand.description: Diagnosing the future food demand and planning how to fulfill the needs of a growing and increasingly affluent population.
example.crop-assimilation-model.descript: Simulating soil, water, and crop processes to better understand crop productivity and monitoring using the Crop Assimilation Model tool in GRASS GIS.
example.water-stress.description: Balancing the ratio of local withdrawal (demand) over the available water (supply).
example.historical-agricultural-land.des: Plotting the historical and future farming trends served.
example.hunger-map.description: Raising awareness about global hunger and places that are in need.
example.agromap.description: Breaking down primary food crops by sub-national administrative districts and aggregating by crop production, area harvested, and crop yields.
example.crop-resilience-to-climate-chang: Adapting to climate change and shifting weather patterns by promoting the continued health of your fields.
example.crop-productivity.description: Calibrating crop productivity using indices like Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) to estimate global crop productivity.
example.erosion-productivity-impact-calc: Prioritizing cropland conservation program implementations through “Model Simulation of Soil Loss, Nutrient Loss, and Change in Soil Organic Carbon Associated with Crop Production”.
example.agriculture-capability.descripti: Classifying the varying potential for agricultural production using the Canadian Land Inventory.
example.ranch-pasture-management.descrip: Collecting soil types, fence lines, roads, and other data for better management for more meaningful reports and maps.
example.agricultural-pollution.descripti: Quantifying the impacts on climate and the environment from agricultural pollution.
example.agriculture-revenue.description: Determining the Effective Opportunity Cost relating to deforestation and potential agricultural revenue with IDRISI GeOSIRIS for REDD.
example.irrigation.description: Capturing irrigation infrastructure for land management decisions more than two-thirds of the world’s freshwater withdrawals are for irrigating crops.
example.farm-preservation.description: Establishing farm priority zones by analyzing the local farming landscape and constructing criteria for high-quality farming areas.
example.versatile-soil-moisture-budget.d: Simulating soil moisture conditions of cropland areas taking into account evapotranspiration, rainfall, runoff, and other factors.
example.drought.description: Minimizing the impact of drought by analyzing the spatial distribution of rainfall and real-time sensors like SMAP, SMOS, and synthetic aperture radar.
example.cropscape.description: Estimating acreage of crop types and spatial distribution using satellite imagery with National Agricultural Statistics Services.
example.crop-forecasting.description: Predicting crop yields using NDVI, weather, soil moisture, soil types, and other parameters.
example.organic-farming.description: Managing various sources of data for organic farming permits including tillage history, field inputs, crop rotations, and pest management measures on a field-by-field basis.
example.agricultural-non-point-source-(a: Predicting the effects of agriculture on water quality using the Agricultural Non-Point Source pollution model in MapWindow
example.drainage-ditches.description: Tracing farm field drainage lines using stereo imagery in MicroImages TNTMips.
example.length-of-growing-period.descrip: Meeting the full evapotranspiration demands of crops when average temperatures are greater or equal to 5°C and precipitation plus moisture stored in the soil exceeds half the potential evapotranspiration.
example.asteroids.description: Gazing the sky and tracking asteroids with NASA’s bolide events map.
example.mapping-mars-with-mola.descripti: Start mapping a whole entire new planet using NASA’s MOLA.
example.mars-terrain.description: Going for a spin on the rugged terrain of Mars using data captured by the Mars Orbiter Laser Altimeter (MOLA) instrument on the Mars Global Surveyor (MGS).
example.mars-rover-landing.description: Examining how to land the Mars Rover safely with operations criteria including latitude for solar power, soil softness, slopes using laser altimetry, dustiness, rockiness, and a landing footprint.
example.water-flow-on-mars.description: Hillshading the Mars Digital Elevation Model to augment legibility and understand where rivers may have flowed and oceans flourished.
example.satellite-orbits.description: Gazing the sky for satellites and even programming satellites for image acquisition.
example.magnetic-fields.description: Investigating magnetic field lines in 3D with international geomagnetic field maps.
example.astrogeology.description: Delivering planetary mapping to the international scientific community in the public domain – from planetary topology to lunar geology. (Astrogeology Science Centre)
example.ufo-sightings.description: Speculating UFO sightings with proportional symbols with over 90,000 reports dating back to 1905.
example.light-pollution.description: Recognizing the artificial light introduced by humans in the night sky and how it interferes with the observation of stars.
example.mars-in-google-earth.description: Searching for Martian landmarks with Google Earth’s “Live from Mars” layer.
example.international-space-station.desc: Tracking the real-time location of the International Space Station (ISS) in ArcGIS Online Data.
example.venus.description: Mapping the altimetry, shaded relief, and geology of Venus.
example.magnetic-declination.description: Positioning with the magnetic declination, a varying angle from a true geographic north using NOAA National Geophysical Data Center 2015 data and the Magnetic Declination QGIS Plugin.
example.gravity-anomaly.description: Understanding our Earth’s gravity by mapping the unusual concentrations of mass in different regions on Earth.
example.nasa-visible-earth.description: Cataloging images and animations of our home planet in the electromagnetic spectrum from various sensors.
example.tycho.description: Mapping Tycho, the youngest moon crater.
example.milky-way.description: Surveying the inner part of the Milky Way Galaxy with GLIMPSE
example.lost-cities.description: Revealing lost cities in the ground by using ground-penetrating radar and infrared sensors. (LiDAR uncovers lost cities)
example.archaeological-survey.descriptio: Tackling huge problems archaeologists face every day – collecting physical locations of their excavation findings from a wealth of sites.
example.middle-eastern-geodatabase-for-a: Recording, monitoring, and protecting archaeological sites to avoid impacting, factor cost for site mitigation – developed by the Getty Conservation Institute (GCI) and the World Monuments Fund (WMF).
example.geographic-text-analysis.descrip: Incorporating a semi-automated exploration of written texts combining Natural Language Processing techniques, Corpus Linguistics and GIS.
example.qgis-archaeology-tools.descripti: Computerizing the archaeological community with their record-keeping with the pyArchInit QGIS plugin.
example.mediterranean-landscape-dynamics: Modeling surface process change and landscape evolution to better understand the long-term interactions of humans and landscapes in the Mediterranean using GRASS GIS.
example.preliminary-site-investigation.d: Searching ancient maps for buildings, cemeteries, roads, and fences as these sites present important clues to archaeological sites.
example.stone-tools.description: Characterizing geographic features suitable for making stone tools and clay pottery such as lithic materials, water resources, stream hydrology with geologic controls like bedrock outcrops and drainage basin floodplains.
example.viewshed.description: Understanding the impacts of how a transmission line would look using viewsheds.
example.archaeological-site-prediction.d: Connecting favorable slope, aspect, geology, hydrology, and distance to water using the Multiple Criteria Evaluation (MCE) to predict archaeological sites.
example.cultural-heritage-inventory.desc: Customizing and deploying the collection of cultural heritage field observations with open source geospatial software Arches.
example.3d-archaeology.description: Rendering accurate and efficient 3D recordings of archaeological heritage sites, in particular, archaeological excavations with aerial imagery and 3D environments.
example.shovel-test-pits.description: Logging transects, shovel test pits, and other recordings when they visit potential locations to conduct field investigations.
example.predicting-dinosaur-tracks.descr: Getting the inside track on understanding exactly where dinosaurs once roamed the Earth with vegetation coverage, slope, aspect, and proximity to landslides.
example.line-of-sight.description: Planning high-rise buildings so they don’t obstruct the view of other buildings using the line of sight tool.
example.exposure-to-noise.description: Orchestrating urban mobility plans with special consideration for the impact of environmental noise.
example.development-planning.description: Making citizens happy through smart development planning and understanding the bigger picture.
example.crowd-simulation.description: Mastering the collective dynamics of interacting objects in urban phenomena at the scale of individual households, people, and units of real estate and at time scales approaching “real-time”.
example.solar-exposure.description: Harvesting light to assess the suitability of installing solar (photovoltaic) panels on roofs using 3D city models and geometric information such as the tilt, orientation, and area of the roof.
example.city-engine.description: Assessing feasibility and plan implementation using Esri’s City Engine improving urban planning, architecture, and overall design.
example.pedestrian-behavior.description: Discerning the movements of pedestrians and urban behavior throughout a plaza in Copenhagen.
example.shadow-analysis.description: Diagnosing the amount of casted shadow in the pre-construction phase onto its surrounding using Bentley Map.
example.parking-availability.description: Orchestrating parking available by collecting the percent of spaces occupied versus search time.
example.integration-of-gis-and-bim.descr: Operating a facility with BIM (building information modeling) because of its ability to analyze information and integrate data from different systems.
example.tangible-landscape.description: Experimenting with the potential impact of different building configurations with an easy-to-use 3D sketching tool.
example.geodesign.description: Conceptualizing building plans with a focus on stakeholder participation and collaboration to closely follow natural systems.
example.propagation-of-noise-in-urban-en: Propagation of Noise in Urban Environments
Modelling 3D data to answer how urban citizens are harmed by noise pollution, and how to mitigate it with noise barriers.
example.space-utilization.description: Augmenting NASA’s Langley Research Center by applying optimization algorithms to space utilization.
example.ordnance-survey-geovation.descri: Pioneering location innovation in the United Kingdom through Geovation – the collaboration, exchange of ideas, and inspiring innovation.
example.quantarctica.description: Familiarizing yourself with the Antarctic with the free, open-source source collection of geographical datasets.
example.exclusive-economic-zones.descrip: Carving out boundaries in the Arctic – Canada, Norway, Russia, Denmark (via Greenland), and the United States are limited to their economic adjacent to their coasts while all waters beyond are considered international water.
example.shipping-route-shortcuts.descrip: Transporting goods through the Arctic passage because of melting ice in the North Pole.
example.sea-ice-motion.description: Maintaining an inventory of sea ice extents snapshots from NOAA’s National Snow and Ice Data Center.
example.aspect.description: Using aspect and incoming solar radiation data to understand how glaciers accumulate on the poleward side.
example.subglacial-lakes.description: Mapping lakes under glaciers – isolated from the outside world for up to 35 million years, and may be final refuges for life, the like of which exists nowhere else on Earth.
example.antarctic-digital-magnetic-anoma: Uncovering the tectonic evolution using near-surface magnetic anomaly data.
example.wildlife-tracking.description: Logging the species richness of marine mammals like whales, seals, walruses and narwhals, and seabirds or waterfowl in the Arctic.
example.sea-ice-index.description: Bringing together data on Antarctica’s ice sheet surface, thickness, and boundary using passive remote sensing. (Sea NSIDC Ice Index)
example.fish.description: Showing the probability of occurrence and observations for fish species – from Atlantic cod to Walleye Pollock.
example.arctic-research-projects.descrip: Displaying research projects, showing available data, and exploring possible collaborations.
example.arctic-ocean-floor.description: Sculpting the Arctic Ocean with the sonic depth finder and discovering dynamics with trenches, ridges, and abyssal plains.
example.arctic’s-geology.description: Interpreting the geology of the Arctic using enhanced magnetic data, Landsat imagery, and topographic data.
example.comnap-facilities.description: Mapping out the COMNAP facilities in Antarctica that currently supports a range of scientific research.
example.polar-bear.description: Keeping counts of the most vulnerable populations of polar bears (due to climate change) by comparing two satellite images over time.
example.search-and-rescue.description: Rescuing missing people by using small, highly maneuverable unmanned aerial vehicles (drones).
example.environmental-risk.description: Assessing the environmental vulnerability of marine resources with respect to oil spills as external stressors.
example.polar-ice-melt.description: Monitoring the polar ice melt using satellites like GOCE and GRACE that measures how much mass is on Earth.
example.stream-order.description: Defining stream size based on a hierarchy of tributaries the Strahler Index (or Horton-Strahler Index) – an important indicator of fisheries and aquatic habitat.
example.fish-habitat-models.description: Connecting fish species with their habitat using habitat suitability indexes.
example.whale-tracking.description: Stalking pigmy killer, sperm, beaked and false killer whales in the Pacific Ocean with online mapping applications.
example.global-shark-tracker.description: Monitoring shark recovery rates with acoustic tags allowing detection in multiple dimensions.
example.fish-eradication.description: Eradicating Northern pike which negatively affects local trout fishery and the economy by tracking their movements with GPS.
example.spawning-sites.description: Drawing spawning site boundaries for migratory fish that are known to release eggs.
example.hydro-acoustics.description: Listening to echoes with hydro-acoustics for the Crean Lake Hydro-Acoustics project – capturing lake depth, fish class, fish stock numbers, and habitat preference related to temperature. (Crean Lake Hydro-Acoustics)
example.mercury-in-stream.description: Grasping the origin of mercury – which are contaminants to fish tissue – by studying the landscape such as soils and humus.
Fine-tuning fish habitat conservation areas by knowing the big picture of fish distribution.
example.overfishing.description: Maintaining sustainable fish population levels with satellite monitoring of sea surface temperature and ocean colors (because they are indicative of specific fish species).
example.stress-monitoring.description: Correlating fish stresses from the local environment such as heat stress from the removal of trees along a stream.
example.scimap.description: Identifying locations of diffuse pollution risk for polluted water and aquatic habitat using SCIMAP.
example.live-air-traffic.description: Turning your computer into an air traffic control center using Flight Radar 24.
example.airplane-identification.descript: Pointing your phone to the sky and identifying airplanes above you using Flight Radar 24.
example.world’s-busiest-airports.descrip: Surfing the world’s top 25 busiest airports with the Esri Global Crossroads Story Map.
example.voronoi-diagram.description: Discovering that Mataveri Airport in Easter Island is the most remote airport in the world with the Voronoi airport proximity map.
example.obstruction-evaluation.descripti: Securing safe take-offs and landings with the Federal Aviation Agency’s (FAA) vertical obstruction database
example.flight-path.description: Simulating flight paths integrated with elevation data, imagery, and other spatial data using Falcon View.
example.search-for-flight-mh370.descript: Crowd-sourcing the search for flight MH370 with satellite imagery provided by DigitalGlobe.
example.airspace-builder.description: Visualizing the air available to aircraft to fly in with 3D volumes using NASA’s World Wind. (NASA World Wind)
example.air-traffic-control.description: Fine-tuning air traffic control with a common operational picture for security vulnerability and land use permitting.
example.drone-no-fly-zones.description: Delineating drone no-fly zones where it’s illegal to fly such as near airports and military bases.
example.aeronautical-charts.description: Scouting out the best routes, safe altitudes, and navigation aids in the sky with aeronautical charts.
example.runway-approach-zone-encroachmen: Pinpointing obstructions in the approach zone of a runway using detailed elevation data to ensure no collisions FAA Safety Analysis.
example.airport-sound-exposure.descripti: Assessing the relationship between aircraft-generated noise levels and land uses, noise receptors, and demographics in the airport environs.
example.fly-through.description: Cruising the high altitudes with interactive 3D viewing and fly-throughs with Landserf.
example.flight-simulator.description: Becoming a pilot in the cockpit with three-dimensional perspective views of an area by combined with elevation and imagery.
example.air-space-review.description: Automating the dissemination and portrayal of Special Activity Airspace information via OGC Web Services.
example.toyota-vehicle-crowd-sourcing.de: Piecing together hyper-precise and up-to-date maps using the Toyota vehicle’s GPS and camera.
example.in-vehicle-usage.description: Monitoring driving habits like speed, sudden acceleration, and pushing hard on the brakes for insurance underwriting.
example.geofencing.description: Immobilizing cross-border travel with geofencing (virtual barriers) – perfect for car sharing and rental programs.
example.self-driving-vehicles.descriptio: Sitting back and relaxing while Google’s autonomous car does all the work equipped with LiDAR, GPS, an inertial unit, and sophisticated software.
example.gps-receivers.description: Nurturing mapping technology as it’s almost standard to have a GPS receiver and a monitor with all the latest maps.
example.waze-real-time-driving.descripti: Saving time and money on your commute as drivers share real-time traffic information and road alerts with each other with Waze.
example.estimated-travel-time.descriptio: Locking in your destination and getting live updates for estimated travel time.
example.morgan-freeman’s-voice.descripti: Enjoying the calm, soothing voice of Morgan Freeman as he delivers directions from your GPS navigation system.
example.market-share.description: Examining branch locations, competitor locations, and demographic characteristics to identify areas worthy of expansion or determine market share.
example.atm-machine.description: Filling in market and service gaps by understanding where customers, facilities, and competitors are with address locating, database management, and query tools.
example.world-bank-economic-statistics.d: Slicing and dicing raw financial data from the World Bank.
example.merger-and-acquisitions.descript: Profiling and finding opportunities to gain and build where customers are with market profiling
example.supply-and-demand.description: Identifying under-served areas and analyzing your competitor’s market.
example.community-reinvestment-act-(cra): Fulfilling the obligations to loan in areas with particular attention to low- and moderate-income households – using GIS to understand spatial demographics.
example.mobile-banking.description: Capturing locations where existing mobile transactions occur and assisting in mobile security infrastructure.
example.fleet-management.description: Staying in route and solving scheduling problems with fleet management.
example.augmented-reality.description: Pulling up engineering diagrams and real-time sensor networks to view water pressure or amperage.
example.direct-marketing.description: Revitalizing selling strategies by reaching out to customers directly with locational intelligence.
example.drive-time-analysis.description: Determining a trade area based on how long a customer must drive to get to the store – factoring in street speed limits, traffic volumes, and other impedance.
example.internet-of-things.description: Improving efficiency, accuracy, and economic benefit through a network of physical objects such as devices, vehicles, buildings, and other items—embedded with electronics, software, sensors, and network connectivity that enables these objects to collect and exchange information with one another.
example.market-share-analysis.descriptio: Optimizing the locations of facilities so the allocated demand is maximized in the presence of competitors using tools like location-allocation in ArcGIS.
example.nearest-location.description: Resolving the nearest gas station, restaurant, or coffee shop using GPS-based positioning and geocoded business data.
example.property-appraisal.description: Appraising residential properties using Census data and finding your property online through interactive property assessment viewers.
example.internet-geocoding.description: Mapping and analyzing user-generated geocoded data to get a glimpse of what internet users (in the aggregate) think about particular places.
example.geocoding-businesses.description: Pinpointing anything to everything from restaurants, banks, and donut shops with a list of addresses.
example.reverse-geocoding.description: Geocoding in reverse; taking locations from a map and listing their addresses.
example.daytime-population.description: Marketing products effectively with detailed daytime population demographics for an area reflecting who works in that area as opposed to residential demographics.
example.local-advertising.description: Advertising through social, local, and mobile mediums through location and making presence more known.
example.tax-havens.description: Sheltering tax through tax havens then putting it all on a map. (Open Corporates)
example.geobranding.description: Increasing credibility and increasing sales with prospective clients, vendors, and media by conveying complex data to increase sales.
example.desire-lines.description: Plotting desire lines showing stores that serve customers.
example.commercial-establishments.descri: Updating commercial establishment using gvSIG Mobile and local databases. (Commercial Establishment Database)
example.supply-chain.description: Finding which supply chains are vulnerable to better plan for interruptions (Boundless Supply Chain)
example.integrated-freight-network-model: Integrating highly detailed information about shipping costs, transfer costs, traffic volumes, and network interconnectivity properties in a GIS-based platform. (Integrated Freight Network Model)
example.capital-projects.description: Listing all the capital projects with different stages of completion.
example.gravity-models.description: Determining the likelihood of customers patronizing a particular store based on the store’s proximity, competition, and other factors.
example.employee-travel-times.descriptio: Modelling travel times in urban networks for employee travel times.
example.store-openings.description: Historicizing a company’s store openings. (IKEA Store Openings)
example.foursquare.description: Recommending 50 million users search for restaurants, recommend bars, and check in around the world with a Mapbox custom branded map. (Foursquare)
example.infrastructure-expansion.descrip: Comparing historical data to current conditions with satellite data from Astro Digital.
example.data-analytics.description: Analyzing location-based information to reveal the relationship between individuals, families, and communities, and the environment in which they live.
example.huff-model.description: Calculating sales potential based on the Huff Model – an interaction model measuring the probabilities of consumers at each origin location patronizing a new store instead of other stores.
example.consumer-profiling.description: Optimizing consumer profiling with location-based information on age, ethnicity, education, housing, and more.
example.retail-customer-segmentation.des: Segmenting markets by customer prototypes to improve the effectiveness of campaigns.
